captivePortal.explanation: A captive portal is the login page that appears when you connect to public Wi-Fi. Hotels, airports, and coffee shops use them to verify guests, accept terms of service, or collect payment. While legitimate portals are common, attackers can create fake ones to steal your credentials. Be cautious: never install apps or enter sensitive information beyond what's absolutely required.

decisionProcess.title: Your Repeatable Decision Process
decisionProcess.subtitle: Use this checklist every time you connect to public Wi-Fi:
decisionProcess.step1Desc: Ask staff for the exact network name. Don't trust similar-looking names.
decisionProcess.step2Desc: Prefer networks with a lock icon (password-protected). Open networks are riskier.
decisionProcess.step3Desc: Before doing anything sensitive, turn on your VPN to encrypt all traffic.
decisionProcess.step4Desc: Banking or passwords? Wait for a secure network. Just browsing? Proceed with caution.
decisionProcess.step5Desc: Decline any prompts to install apps, profiles, or certificates from portals.

rogueHotspot.title: What is a Rogue Hotspot?
rogueHotspot.description: A rogue hotspot (also called an 'evil twin') is a fake Wi-Fi network set up by an attacker to look like a legitimate one. When you connect, they can see your traffic, steal passwords, or redirect you to fake websites.
rogueHotspot.spot1: Names that look almost right but have small differences (hyphens, underscores, extra words)
rogueHotspot.spot2: Networks claiming to be 'FREE' versions of business networks
rogueHotspot.spot3: Open networks with unusually strong signals
rogueHotspot.spot4: Multiple networks with very similar names

cons_trap.title: Fake Network Trap
cons_trap.whatHappened: You connected to 'FREE_Daily_Grind_WiFi' - a fake network set up by an attacker. A convincing login page appeared asking for your email to 'access the internet.' Any credentials you entered were captured.
cons_trap.whyRisky: Attackers often create networks with names similar to legitimate ones (called 'evil twin' attacks). Open networks with enticing names like 'FREE' are major red flags. The fake captive portal harvested your login credentials.
cons_trap.saferAlternative: Always verify the exact network name with staff before connecting. Look for secured networks (with the lock icon) and be suspicious of networks that are open but claim to be from a business.
cons_trap.technicalExplanation: Evil twin attacks work by broadcasting a stronger signal than the legitimate network, causing devices to connect automatically. The attacker then intercepts all traffic or presents fake login pages.
cascading: Your email credentials were captured by the fake login page
Attacker uses your email to reset passwords on other accounts
Your linked bank and shopping accounts are now accessible
Personal data from these accounts enables identity theft

cons_open.title: Unprotected Network
cons_open.whatHappened: You connected to 'FreePublicWiFi' - a completely open network with no encryption. Anyone nearby could potentially see your unencrypted traffic.
cons_open.whyRisky: Open networks with generic names could be set up by anyone. Without encryption, your browsing activity, search queries, and any non-HTTPS data is visible to others on the same network.
cons_open.saferAlternative: Choose networks that require a password (showing a lock icon). Verify the network name with the establishment. If you must use an open network, enable a VPN immediately.
cons_open.technicalExplanation: On unencrypted networks, attackers can use packet sniffing tools to capture network traffic. While HTTPS protects the content of secure websites, metadata like which sites you visit is still visible.

cons_neighbor.title: Connected to Wrong Network
cons_neighbor.whatHappened: You connected to 'Bookstore_Next_Door' - a legitimate network, but not the one for this coffee shop. While probably not malicious, this wasn't the intended network.
cons_neighbor.whyRisky: Connecting to unknown networks, even if they appear legitimate, means trusting an unknown administrator. You have no control over their security practices or logging policies.
cons_neighbor.saferAlternative: Always verify you're connecting to the correct network for your location. Ask staff for the official network name rather than guessing.

cons_autojoin_safe.title: Auto-Join Disabled
cons_autojoin_safe.whatHappened: You turned off auto-join and set the network to forget after use.
cons_autojoin_safe.whyRisky: This reduces the chance your device will reconnect automatically to public Wi-Fi later without you noticing.
cons_autojoin_safe.saferAlternative: Keep auto-join off for public networks and forget them after you leave.
cons_autojoin_safe.technicalExplanation: Auto-join can connect to remembered SSIDs, including look-alike networks. Forgetting removes stored network details.

cons_autojoin_risky.title: Auto-Join Left On
cons_autojoin_risky.whatHappened: You left auto-join enabled for this network.
cons_autojoin_risky.whyRisky: Your device may reconnect automatically later, possibly to a look-alike network with the same name.
cons_autojoin_risky.saferAlternative: Disable auto-join and forget public networks when you're done.
cons_autojoin_risky.technicalExplanation: Devices often reconnect to remembered SSIDs without prompting, which can be exploited by attackers who copy network names.

cons_email_unverified.title: Missed a Safety Step
cons_email_unverified.whatHappened: You checked your email successfully. The network you chose appears legitimate, and your email provider's HTTPS encryption protected your login. However, you connected without verifying with staff that this was the official network.
cons_email_unverified.whyRisky: Here's the problem: You got lucky, but you didn't know you were safe. 'DailyGrind_Guest' looked right, but attackers specifically create convincing names. Without verification, you had no way to distinguish the real network from a well-crafted fake. The 30 seconds it takes to ask staff could prevent hours of dealing with compromised accounts. Building the habit of verification is more important than any single safe connection.
cons_email_unverified.saferAlternative: Before connecting to any public network, ask staff for the exact network name. It only takes a moment, and it turns guessing into a more informed choice. This habit greatly reduces the risk of evil-twin networks, but you should still stay alert for look-alike names and unexpected login pages.
cons_email_unverified.technicalExplanation: Even correctly named networks can be spoofed. Attackers can copy the SSID and use stronger signals to lure devices. Staff verification is the best practical first step, but also check for small spelling differences and be cautious of unexpected captive portals.

hotel_intermediate.title: Business Trip at The Grand Hotel
hotel_intermediate.description: You've arrived at a hotel for a business trip and need to get online. Multiple networks are available, and the front desk is busy. How will you connect safely?

hotel_update_prompt.title: Device Updates
hotel_update_prompt.description: A system update is available before tomorrow's presentation.

task_update_device.title: Install Security Updates
task_update_device.description: Updates often include fixes for security flaws.
task_update_device.riskHint: Delaying updates can leave known vulnerabilities unpatched.

cons_premium.title: Secure Choice
cons_premium.whatHappened: You chose the premium, password-protected network. This provides WPA2 encryption between your device and the access point, making it much harder for other hotel guests to eavesdrop on your traffic.
cons_premium.whyRisky: This is a much safer choice than the open network. Here's why it matters: on the free open network, any guest with basic tools could capture your traffic. The premium network's password creates unique encryption keys for your session. The $15 investment is worthwhile when you're handling business data. Keep in mind that you're still on shared infrastructure, and network administrators could potentially see some metadata, so treat it as lower risk, not zero risk.
cons_premium.saferAlternative: For maximum protection, use a VPN even on the premium network. But your choice was solid - you recognized that network security has real value, especially when doing business work.
cons_premium.technicalExplanation: WPA2 uses the shared password to derive unique encryption keys for each connected device through a four-way handshake. Unlike open networks where packets can be read in the air, your data is encrypted in a way that is difficult for nearby users to decode without your session keys.

cons_update_now.title: Updates Installed
cons_update_now.whatHappened: You installed security updates before continuing.
cons_update_now.whyRisky: Keeping your device updated reduces exposure to known vulnerabilities that attackers target on public networks.
cons_update_now.saferAlternative: Great choice. Enable automatic updates when possible to stay protected without extra steps.
cons_update_now.technicalExplanation: Security updates patch known flaws in the operating system and browser that could otherwise be exploited.

cons_update_later.title: Updates Postponed
cons_update_later.whatHappened: You chose to delay the updates.
cons_update_later.whyRisky: Postponing updates can leave known security holes open, which is a bigger risk on shared networks.
cons_update_later.saferAlternative: Update before sensitive work whenever you can, especially while traveling.
cons_update_later.technicalExplanation: Attackers often target publicly known vulnerabilities that are already fixed by patches.

airport_advanced.title: Layover at Metro Airport
airport_advanced.description: You have a 2-hour layover and need to finish some urgent work tasks. The airport is crowded and you see many available networks. Time is of the essence.

airport_cert_warning.title: Certificate Warning
airport_cert_warning.description: A security warning appears when you open the contract portal.

cert_abort.label: Go back and choose a safer option

task_cert_warning.title: Certificate Warning
task_cert_warning.description: The browser says the site's certificate can't be verified.
task_cert_warning.riskHint: Certificate warnings can indicate interception or a fake site.

cons_mobile.title: Excellent Decision Under Pressure
cons_mobile.whatHappened: Despite the stress and time pressure, you chose to use your mobile data hotspot instead of any airport Wi-Fi. This is one of the most secure options available to you.
cons_mobile.whyRisky: This was a strong choice, and here's why it matters: Mobile data avoids the shared Wi-Fi segment that enables most local attacks. Intercepting cellular traffic is possible but typically requires specialized equipment and is far less common in normal settings. For urgent, high-stakes work like signing contracts, mobile data is often the safest practical choice.
cons_mobile.saferAlternative: You made a strong choice. The main trade-offs are battery use and data costs, but for critical work the reduced Wi-Fi risk is worth it.
cons_mobile.technicalExplanation: Cellular networks (LTE/5G) use mandatory encryption between your device and the cell tower. Interception generally requires specialized equipment and expertise, which makes it less likely than typical Wi-Fi attacks. For practical purposes, mobile data is generally safer than public Wi-Fi.

cons_sign_mobile.title: Contract Signed Securely
cons_sign_mobile.whatHappened: You signed the legally binding contract while connected through your mobile data. This avoided most of the Wi-Fi-specific risks present in the airport.
cons_sign_mobile.whyRisky: Risk is low. Your cellular connection uses strong encryption between your phone and the carrier's cell tower, and nearby attackers have far fewer opportunities than on Wi-Fi. However, no network is risk-free, and the signing portal's HTTPS security still matters.
cons_sign_mobile.saferAlternative: You made an excellent choice. For extremely sensitive contracts, some teams require hardware tokens or in-person signing. For routine business contracts, mobile data is one of the most practical high-security options on the go.
cons_sign_mobile.technicalExplanation: Mobile data uses LTE/5G encryption that is far harder to intercept locally than Wi-Fi. Combined with the HTTPS encryption of the signing portal, your credentials and signed document were protected by multiple layers. Local attackers at the airport had little opportunity to interfere.

cons_cert_abort.title: Heeded the Warning
cons_cert_abort.whatHappened: You stopped and did not proceed past the certificate warning.
cons_cert_abort.whyRisky: Certificate warnings can indicate interception or a fake portal. Stopping avoids handing credentials to the wrong site.
cons_cert_abort.saferAlternative: Use mobile data or try a verified network, then re-open the portal.
cons_cert_abort.technicalExplanation: Invalid or mismatched certificates are a common sign of man-in-the-middle attacks on public Wi-Fi.

cons_cert_proceed.title: Warning Ignored
cons_cert_proceed.whatHappened: You continued despite the certificate warning.
cons_cert_proceed.whyRisky: If the warning was caused by interception, your login could be exposed or the page could be a fake.
cons_cert_proceed.saferAlternative: Back out and use mobile data or a verified network before proceeding.
cons_cert_proceed.technicalExplanation: Certificate warnings appear when the browser cannot verify the site's identity. On public Wi-Fi, attackers can exploit this to intercept credentials.

briefing.title: Quick Briefing
briefing.description: Take a moment to plan before you connect.

bestChoice.body: Ask staff for the official network and use the password-protected option. If you cannot verify, avoid sensitive tasks or use a VPN.

protect.body: Your work email, banking credentials, and personal data. These can be used to reset other accounts.

tradeoff.body: Verification or waiting takes a minute, and postponing tasks can be inconvenient, but it lowers risk.

bestChoice.body: Confirm the official SSID at the front desk. Prefer the premium network or use a VPN on the free network. Decline app installs.

protect.body: Work email, presentation files, and hotel account details like room number and last name.

tradeoff.body: Premium access costs money and VPN setup takes time, but both reduce exposure on shared hotel networks.

bestChoice.body: Use your mobile hotspot for urgent work. If you must use Wi-Fi, verify the official network name and enable a VPN.

protect.body: Contract credentials, corporate accounts, and the signed document.

tradeoff.body: Mobile data uses battery and may cost data, and waiting in line reduces time, but both cut Wi-Fi risk.

debrief.title: Quick Debrief
debrief.description: Reflect on how your choices affected risk.

doDifferently.title: What you'd do differently next time

didWell.body: If you verified the network, used a VPN, or postponed banking, you made strong safety choices.

doDifferently.body: Next time, verify first before connecting and avoid open networks for email or banking. Some choices are good enough but not best; for high-stakes tasks, aim for a verified network plus VPN or mobile data.

habit.body: Enable 2FA on work accounts, make "verify the network name" your default habit, and use a VPN on public Wi-Fi.

didWell.body: If you verified the SSID, avoided installing apps, or used a VPN, you lowered risk.

doDifferently.body: Treat open hotel Wi-Fi as risky; use VPN or mobile data for sensitive work. Some options are acceptable but not optimal when the stakes are high.

habit.body: Enable 2FA on work accounts, never install captive portal apps, and always verify the network name on each stay.

didWell.body: If you used mobile data or a VPN, you reduced risk under intense time pressure.

doDifferently.body: Do not chase the strongest signal; verify names character by character when stakes are high. Premium or verified Wi-Fi can be good enough, but mobile data or VPN is the safer standard for critical tasks.

habit.body: Enable 2FA on work accounts, default to mobile data for high-stakes tasks, and disable auto-join for public Wi-Fi.
